title: Conventional Commits Guide
directions: A specification for adding human and machine readable meaning to commit messages

types.name: style
types.description: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing semi-colons, etc)

types.name: refactor
types.description: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature

types.name: perf
types.description: A code change that improves performance

types.name: test
types.description: Adding missing tests or correcting existing tests
types.example: test: add unit tests for user authentication

types.name: build
types.description: Changes that affect the build system or external dependencies

types.name: ci
types.description: Changes to our CI configuration files and scripts
types.example: ci: add new GitHub Actions workflow

types.name: chore
types.description: Other changes that don't modify src or test files

scope.description: Provides additional contextual information about the changes

rules: Use the imperative mood in the description
Do not end with a period

body.description: Provides a detailed explanation of the changes
rules: Separate from the description with a blank line

footer.description: Used for additional information like breaking changes or issue references
rules: Separate from the body with a blank line
Common footers: BREAKING CHANGE, closes #issue-number, etc.
examples: BREAKING CHANGE: The user API has been completely restructured

format: Or use ! after the type/scope: feat!: change API structure
examples: BREAKING CHANGE: Users must now provide API key

with_breaking_change: BREAKING CHANGE: removes support for v1 API
with_issue_reference: fix: resolve memory leak in data processing\n\ncloses #1234

benefits: Communicate the nature of changes to teammates
